author: disorientedcheerio
body:
Just my two cents, but I like to compare $SBE to Enphase Energy ($ENPH) in terms of growth. $ENPH is even listed as a benchmark company for ChargePoint, in terms of public space, in $SBE's investor presentation here: [http://switchback-energy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/ChargePoint-New-Investor-Deck-23-Sept-2020-8K.pdf](http://switchback-energy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/ChargePoint-New-Investor-Deck-23-Sept-2020-8K.pdf)

ChargePoint had an implied valuation of 2.4 billion when $SBE was $10 per share. I believe a fair valuation for ChargePoint as a company will be about 8-9 billion in a year, similar to where $ENPH is now. Given that valuation, my price target for $SBE would be around $20 before the merger, which implies a valuation of around 5 billion.

It's best to just invest now, no reason to try and time it. This is a solid company with products that everyone already loves.

author: GromGrommeta
body:
It sounds like your problem is trading rather than coming up with solid long-term theses that allow you to view temporary dips as opportunities. You don't mention in any of your paragraphs why you bought what you bought except for ENPH being down because of a news article.

I do understand position sizing and FOMO. I started buying TDOC in the 30s, maybe 5-10 shares each purchase. Looking back sure, I wish it was 50-100 shares I was purchasing. But you gotta have a strategy and stick to it. I accumulate positions in speculative companies slowly and have specific results/metrics I want to see before making them a main position. 

Of course, this is investing advice that takes a long-term mindset. If you want trading advice and a short-term mindset, there's a few other subs for that. But speaking from experience, a short-term mindset will continue to weigh on your mental health.

author: Zairieminx
body:
This is coming from an uninformed investor so take what you will. Some may downvote me, or agree, but you might have one too many different stocks. You're trying to cover all bases(I did this as well), but I started to understand it's far too much stress. If you feel like watching 19 different ETF or stocks that's great, but which to add too is where it gets tricky and stressful.

In fact, I just sold off some stocks and ETF's to get myself back under 10 currently at 9 different holdings, and the amount of stress that takes away is actually noticeable. 

ARKF if not mistaken is Financial Tech so I would think they have SQ themselves for example. Might be better to hold it vs just SQ alone, but that's your choice of course. 

&#x200B;

P.S just word to the wise this is hindsight, but I didn't realize VSLR was @ 32.64 I've had 3 different stocks in very cheap territory and could have made a killing ENPH and AMD were the other two. 

AMD was in at $1.43, ENPH @ 1.50, and VSLR @ 4.5 this was couple years ago. 

What could have been....................

author: verstehenie
body:
If you’re looking for value in this area, you have to go against the herd to an extent.  TSLA is a great company, but its valuation won’t make sense for another 5 years.  It’s similar with SEDG and ENPH; good companies, but expensive (SMA/S92 is my pick in the inverter space).  On the other hand, I think there is a strong bull case for solar module manufacturers over the next few years because they are currently profitable even with record low prices/LCOE.  Lower module costs drive demand growth for commercial- and utility-scale solar, and companies like JKS, CSIQ, and FSLR are bulking up capacity to benefit.  I particularly like JKS due to its high growth and market share, but as of this week those are starting to get priced in.

Most of the other companies I’m in are probably overvalued.  Siemens-Gamesa and Vestas are well-positioned for growth, but expensive relative to earnings.  Same with Ørsted, although earnings from asset divestiture are lumpy.  BEP might be a decent buy.  One company I’m currently excited about is the developer/asset owner Neoen, who commissioned that record-breaking [Tesla battery in Australia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hornsdale_Power_Reserve).  They are growing aggressively, with the kind of vision (and, frankly, leverage) that the climate situation demands, but that makes them risky.  I’m also in a handful of hydrogen companies (NEL/D7G, ITM/IJ8, and BLDP), but those are highly speculative at this point.

author: michael370662
body:
Energy sector shift is a long term play. Nuclear energy and solar had all moved up. can take a look at CCJ and ENPH.

Coal play is short term bullish, long term bearish. 

All coal miners are currently below their fair value, it's a value play, not a long term play. If you look at VALE, PBR, SSL, they all had not returned back to Feb valuation. Coal is the same. Would you be long term bullish on oil when TSLA will replace gas station? 

But in the near term, these will go back to a fair valuation before the slow grind down. 

I had no benefits from this, why would I pump and dump. It make sense if I had a position and try to get out but I don't. (those few shares that I have won't make back what I lose)

author: _blk_swn_
body:
So look, anyone could tell you your highly concentrated. But i’ma tell you this

1) you are fucking highly concentrated in some of the largest and most volatile large cap tech companies. TSLA, AAPL, and ENPH will move together since they have overlapping revenues (meaning semiconductors often fuel smartphone and other computer processing companies. 

2) SPCE is just getting its footing and Islas a long road ahead of it. Your time horizon, and if you are playing with stocks; Seems to be 1y+. But since you are on this site, I doubt you were thinking multi-year gains. Volatility will happen. Accept it. You are only down 2k. Ever lose 100k? How about 500k?  If you haven’t. Don’t be complaining. Try managing someone else’s money then having to explain to them why they are down 50% after giving you 25m to manage 3 weeks prior. 2k is small on the grand scale of things. It’s not about how much you lose, it’s about how fast you bounce back. 

3) Vol happens, live with it, love it, embrace it, trade it. Vol can be your best friend or worse nightmare. In your case, having some pretty volatile stocks doesn’t help and you’ll be exposed to it more often. Just realize that. Additionally, the market is kinda over extended, SPY and SPX calls are not being rolled up primarily cause we got an election coming and investors feel like we need a 5-10% pullback. It could happen, but historically, trading before an election is usually pretty choppy. So get used to it.

If you can trade options, use that to offset losses. Or, take some gains off the table and keep in cash for if the market dips

author: SaveThemTurdles
body:
I’d strongly urge you to avoid cannabis stock for now. It seems like a promising, untapped market but no cannabis company has been proven to be successful so far with a good long term outlook. Pretty much every cannabis stock has crashed with no signs of recovery. 

If you want to invest long term into the future, consider the renewable energy sector, especially solar. Solar is the fastest growing renewable energy sector, expected to take up about 50% of the renewable energy sector by 2050. I hold SEDG, ENPH, and TAN. 

Other than that, tech, fintech, health, and EVs, have a great future outlook in my opinion.

author: disorientedcheerio
body:
I'm just going to re-comment what I stated in another $SBE thread. First of all, SPACs never buy a whole company. Most of the shares are held by people in the acquired company. For example, $SHLL only bought 14% of Hyliion, per their investor presentation: [https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1759631/000121390020015311/ea123187ex99-3\_tortoiseacq.htm](https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1759631/000121390020015311/ea123187ex99-3_tortoiseacq.htm)

And my personal DD on $SPE from the same thread:

>Just my two cents, but I like to compare $SBE to Enphase Energy ($ENPH) in terms of growth. $ENPH is even listed as a benchmark company for ChargePoint, in terms of public space, in $SBE's investor presentation here: [http://switchback-energy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/ChargePoint-New-Investor-Deck-23-Sept-2020-8K.pdf](http://switchback-energy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/ChargePoint-New-Investor-Deck-23-Sept-2020-8K.pdf)  
>  
>ChargePoint had an implied valuation of 2.4 billion when $SBE was $10 per share. I believe a fair valuation for ChargePoint as a company will be about 8-9 billion in a year, similar to where $ENPH is now. Given that valuation, my price target for $SBE would be around $20 before the merger, which implies a valuation of around 5 billion.  
>  
>It's best to just invest now, no reason to try and time it. This is a solid company with products that everyone already loves.

$SBE / ChargePoint has great growth potential. I currently have 3,500 common shares @ 12.95.

author: mercury2six
body:
I hate this stock along with enph. I have serious hindsight on these two. 
Had a hundred shares of enph early last year around $9/share. I sold happily around 12/share. 
Vslr this summer I bought 10 calls at an 11 strike. Paid $800. I normally don't hold those very long. I held these contracts for over a month and carried the bag the entire time. I finally cut my losses and took a near 45% loss. 
The fucking same day I closed my calls out, they announced the merger and skyrocketed. 
So now I just own TAN.

author: SteveSharpe
body:
I am in the industry, and CrowdStrike makes a good product, but endpoint security solutions seem to come and go in popularity all the time.  A few years ago the hot one was Carbon Black.  Now it's CrowdStrike with all the hype.

I suspect in a few years something new and better will emerge.  Cybersecurity is tough to invest in because it changes so rapidly.  Rather than invest in a point solution company, I'd recommend looking at a security company that is much more diverse like a Fortinet or Palo Alto Networks.

author: SolitaryEgg
body:
The year: 2074.

I'm an old man now. My body is a shell of what it once was. My wife left this world some years ago. That's when the joy left. That's when hope left. 

I'm not a religious man, but I sometimes allow my mind to slip away as I imagine holding her again. I run my fingers through her strawberry-blonde hair. Maybe it's in heaven, or some other ethereal place. I don't believe, but pretending that I do makes me feel alive again, if only for one fleeting moment. 

I turn on my neuralink and close my eyes. I flip through old pictures. It's her. For a moment, I can almost smell her in the room. Lavender, and fresh wildflowers. It's enough to bring a strained smile to this old, callous, weathered face.

I open a browser and check the S&P futures. 3536. It hasn't moved in decades now, it would seem. But I keep checking. I don't know why. Maybe the repetition takes my mind off things, or maybe it just reminds me of the old days. When I was happy. 

Sitting in the empty, dusty room, I let out a broken whimper: "futures flat... and gay."

author: hydershykh
body:
Here's a layman explanation for the tool. This might be helpful to the non-tech folks:

So  let's stay there is a day when vaccine comes up, all stocks start to  rally hard and volume increases significantly. It keeps going on for a  few days for many biotech stocks but there is a certain stock X where  the volume keeps increasing but the price isn't increasing similar to  others.

Now in this case, that is  an anomaly or an unusual pattern. What might be happening is rich folks  getting large positions in X and they are pretty sure that it's gonna  rocket in near future. This is what this tool tries to catch - stocks  that behave abnormal relative to the entire stock market.

That's all you need to know, the technicals are not necessary.

Hope this makes more sense.

author: dvdmovie1
body:
"Many people are making the case for a significant correction in markets right now."

Yes, and many have on here since the March low and many have on here for large stretches of the last 5 years and they've been *completely wrong*, or they've been apocalypse-level bearish at the exact wrong time (mid-March, December 2018) or people cheerlead for a market crash (see 2019 on here) and then when one actually happens, people acted in March like people were morons for buying. 

There's a portion of this sub that has been negative for years and has complained when markets are going up ("the market isn't doing what I think it should" is something I've read on here a lot in the last 2 years and really, the market doesn't care what you think it should do; invest in the market that's in front of you, not the market you think it should be), seems *certain* that it is going much lower at bottoms (March, December 18) and then is frustrated and upset when the rebound happens and complains all the way up again ("The Circle of r/investing Bearishness.")

There will be a correction. When will it be? I have no idea and nobody on here has a crystal ball. It might be tomorrow, it might be a 10% correction after the market has already gone another 5% higher.  A 10% correction used to be considered normal and healthy. Now it's like "DEFCON-1" or something. 

Honestly, understand your risk tolerance and the risk in your portfolio, don't invest more than you're comfortable with, don't get complacent, take *some* profit into strength at times and patiently wait to redeploy. Have a *long-term* plan and stick to it. Don't try and avoid every bit of potential turbulence, don't just sell everything every time there *might* be volatility (periods like March are times when there's great opportunities, they're not something to be completely avoided; if you avoid situations that cause market volatility and only get back in when everything is a-okay again, you're actively choosing to avoid opportunities) and honestly, "selling everything" is something that someone should do very, very rarely if ever but it seems to be a more and more common thing on here.

I've posted this what feels hundreds of times on here: "“Far more money has been lost by investors preparing for corrections, or trying to anticipate corrections, than has been lost in corrections themselves.” - Peter Lynch. It's really, *really* true and this sub over the last 5 years has often been a fantastic example of it.

author: orbitbrasil
body: Hey man. Jumping right into a $4k Tesla OTM call is sort of baptism by fire. If you're willing to lose all of that, then stick with it. Obviously, you can gain quite a bit from it as well. I know you're already locked in to that...but I would highly suggest playing around with \~$300 or so to get a feel of how options work before diving head first into a large position (as you have.) Find a ticker that has options with low premiums (WORK is a good one, for example) and test the waters there. From there, you'll learn about how all of this works -- what constitutes as high IV, the effect of theta, etc. Once you get a good (if even possible) grasp on all of this...then you are ready to go. That being said, that Tesla call could very well make you a lot of money. It could also very well lose you a lot of money. Godspeed young one.

author: noentic
body:
Daily Market and Options Summary for Sept 1st, 2020

Daily Synopsis

* The S&P 500 (+0.8%) and Nasdaq Composite (+1.4%) rallied to fresh record highs on Tuesday, with the Nasdaq getting an added boost from the momentum in the mega-caps and growth stocks. The wealth spread around to the Russell 2000 (+1.1%) and Dow Jones Industrial Average (+0.8%), too.
* Today's key moves were Apple (AAPL 134.18, +5.14, +4.0%) rising 4% after JPMorgan raised its price target on the stock to $150 from $115, and Zoom Video (ZM 457.69, +132.59, +40.8%) surging 40% after it crushed Q2 earnings expectations.
* Apple was a major factor in today's index gains given its 7.3% weight in the S&P 500, while Zoom provided the fuel for other growth stocks like Netflix (NFLX 556.55, +26.99, +5.1%) and DocuSign (DOCU 268.80, +45.80, +20.5%). Another supporting factor was the ISM Manufacturing Index for August increasing to 56.0% (consensus 54.5%) from 54.2% in July.
* The manufacturing data helped lift the S&P 500 materials (+2.8%) and industrials (+1.0%) sectors into positive territory with the information technology (+1.9%), communication services (+1.0%), and consumer discretionary (+1.1%) sectors. Each advanced at least 1.0%.
* Conversely, the utilities (-1.1%), health care (-1.0%), and energy (-0.9%) sectors underperformed and declined around 1.0%.
* Recapping some other mega-cap moves, Walmart (WMT 147.59, +8.74, +6.3%) climbed 6% after officially introducing its Walmart+ membership program. Tesla (TSLA 475.05, -23.27, -4.7%), however, was a notable holdout after the company disclosed plans to sell up to $5 billion in stock.
* U.S. Treasuries ended the day higher after reclaiming overnight losses. The 2-yr yield declined two basis points to 0.11%, and the 10-yr yield declined two basis points to 0.67%. The U.S. Dollar Index increased 0.2% to 92.34 after being down 0.4% in the morning. WTI crude futures increased 0.3%, or $0.14, to $42.76/bbl.
* Looking ahead, investors will receive the ADP Employment Change Report for August, the Fed's Beige Book, Factory Orders for July, and the weekly MBA Mortgage Applications Index, and auto and truck sales for August on Wednesday.

Index Summary

**S&P 500 :** (+0.94%);  **NasDaq :** (+1.72%);

author: BenjaminWobbles
body: How much money would it take for you to actually retire, quit work and options, get in something safe and ride it out for the rest of your life? I'm at like 8 million for a basic bitch suburban lifestyle. McMansion, UGG boots, C class Mercedes, daily injections of pumpkin spice latte and an hour a day of yoga. A mother fucker could really settle in for 8 million.
